title: 104_hr2440
content: EMERGENCY PLANNING AND COMMUNITY RIGHT-TO-KNOW. Section 304 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act of 1986 is amended to require the operator of a facility to report any releases within 1 hour of knowledge. The owner or operator of a facility must report any releases within 1 hour to the community emergency coordinator and State emergency planning commission or a State agency authorized to receive such notification. If a State agency is notified, it must inform the State emergency response commission within 2 hours. The owner or operator of a facility must report any releases within 1 hour to the community emergency coordinator and State emergency planning commission or a State agency authorized to receive such notification. Notice may be given later than 1 hour after knowledge of a leak or spill if unable to provide notification due to extenuating circumstances. Transportation incidents can satisfy notice requirements by dialing 911 or calling the operator. The Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 (CERCLA) is a significant environmental law. Amendment to Section 103 of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 requires any person in charge of a vessel or facility to notify the National Response Center or State emergency response commission within 1 hour of a hazardous substance release. The Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 requires immediate notification of hazardous substance releases to the National Response Center or State agencies authorized by law. Notifications must be conveyed within 2 hours to all appropriate Government agencies and the Governor of affected States. If a State agency or person in charge of a vessel or facility notifies the State emergency response commission, the notification must be relayed to the National Response Center within 2 hours. Authorized State agencies must also inform the National Response Center and State emergency response commission within 2 hours of receiving notification. Notifications can be delayed up to 1 hour after knowledge of a leak or spill. The notification of hazardous substance releases must be given within 1 hour of knowledge of the release to the National Response Center, State emergency response commission, or appropriate State agency as designated by State law.
